bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. For over 250 years, the Society has played an important role in American cultural and intellectual life. Until the mid-nineteenth century, the Society fulfilled the role of a national academy of science, national library and museum, and even patent office. Early members of the Society included Thomas Jefferson, David Rittenhouse, Benjamin Rush, Stephen Peter Du Ponceau, George Washington, and many other figures prominent in American history.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of miscellaneous records from several offices of the American Philosophical Society. The collection consists of: office files of Randolph S. Klein on various topics, including meetings, public relations and information requests, fundraising, and members (circa 1980-1990); office files of Jean T. Williams (assistant to the Executive Officer), including files on membership, fundraising, committees, and copies of newsletters (circa 1986-1991); materials related to the Building and Endowment Fund (1912-1937), including a survey and plan of the campaign, ledger of subscriptions, and statements; information on renovations to the buildings owned by the Society; copies of the Society's pension plan (1957-1969); master copies of various American Philosophical Society forms, including applications and agreements for grant recipients and recommendation forms (circa 1940); an inventory of art and artifacts, including locations and conservation work performed; and records concerning a lawsuit filed by Gail Beckman against the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission and APS, including court records, correspondence, and depositions (1966-1983).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
